regions throughout the world that are made up of 66 availability zones and you can think

169 points of presence in our content delivery network means that you can provide low latency access whether

it's automatically deployable into your AWS accounts we provide automation that

examples of customers taking advantage of AWS to do to do next-generation
research within within AWS next-generation medical research and I
think a great example one great example of that is work being done in Stanford University around diabetic retinopathy so diabetic
retinopathy is a complication from diabetes that is the leading cause of blindness in adults and if it's detected
early then it's largely preventable and so there were two students at Stanford University who wanted to kind of explore
the idea well hey if you can detect this by looking at images of someone's eye is
it possible to develop a machine learning model that can look at eye images and detect early signs of
diabetic retinopathy so that you could identify patients patients who need this type of intervention and in fact that's
exactly what they did on AWS they were able to train a machine learning model on a little over 80,000 images of an eye
of people's eyes and develop a machine learning model that could predict or
detect the precursors of diabetic retinopathy and so I think this is a great example of using cloud
capabilities to eliminate kind of undifferentiated heavy lifting or kind
of eliminate IT tasks and focus on research because by taking advantage of the GPU resources that are available in
AWS and the machine learning services that are available on AWS they were able to quickly iterate and not just train a
single machine learning model because for those of you that have worked in machine learning before you know that
it's just like any type of research it's an iterative process right you're going to want to train a model using one
algorithm compare its performance to a model using a different algorithm tune your hyper parameters and they were able to do that
to iterate quickly in order to generate a model that provided good performance to detect these precursor signs and so
again like taking advantage of the cloud and the agility of the cloud in order to focus on research and do research
quickly inside of AWS and another example out of Stanford University
kind of a similar idea but focusing on skin cancer so every year there are 5.4 million cases of skin cancer in the
United States and for skin cancer from melanoma if it's detected early there's
a 97 percent survival rate but if it's detected late that survival rate drops
to just 14% so obviously it's important to detect skin cancer early and skin
cancer is something else that can be detected by looking at imagery by looking at skin lesion imagery and so
that's exactly what another team from Stanford did was they were able to train a machine learning model based on a
hundred and thirty thousand skinned images of 2,000 different types of skin disease and this model is able to
differentiate between skin lesion image that represents cancer and one that does
not and the way that they validated that is they didn't tested their their resultant model against 307 370 skin
lesion images and compared the results to 21 board-certified dermatologists and it performed as well as the 21
board-certified dermatologists so again being able to take advantage of AWS the GPU resources that are available in AWS
in order to focus on training machine learning models and not deploying or configuring servers another really
interesting example I think is Hart flow a commercial organization that's focused on detecting heart disease helping to
helping clinicians to detect heart disease and so again applying machine learning to to train to train a model on
the available data it's they use a non-invasive procedure so a CT scan of someone's heart in order to help
clinicians diagnose heart disease by visualizing blood flow within the arteries of the heart and identifying
areas of blockage so what this does is it helps clinicians understand through the information
available in a CT scan where areas of blockage and it can help them to diagnose heart disease without having to
do invasive procedures like an angiogram and so this you know not having to do those invasive procedures reduces the
cost of care and it also kind of broadens clinicians ability to diagnose
heart disease which is critical again for early detection and again this
application built on top of AWS clinicians are able to use it and not focus on building servers or configuring
Network environments but on using the machine learning model that's made available through through heart flow and
